column4: Another point to remember is that when a computer motherboard was manufactured, it was wave soldered at high temperatures. Much hotter than what the computer runs at.
Acidchild, true. An ongoing temp process will affect the overall change in components.
a lot of soldering is done sonically these days
testing a component by touching it is baseless.  What we consider hot or warm is relative according to manufacturers specifications.
i don't test if my cpu is 90*C by touching it! i've already been burned doing that
is this a laptop or desktop?
laptop

please make sure that your fan motor is not blocked by papers and stuff. Many people put paper on top of the keyboard and so. Also I in some cases use a cookie grill to sit on to allow the heat dispersion.

the fan is not blocked, i actually pulled out a nice clump of dust when i took off the heat sink when i replaced the mobo; it's in a cabinet but the bottom is propped up and i've been keeping the doors open; i've also forced the fan to stay on high speed all the time; it just gets hot when streaming video
streaming video uses up a lot of CPU though. That is not unusual.
so its ok to be 90*C then?
i'm probably going to get rid of the cabinet altogether once we get a new tv, since the tv will hang on the wall
putting a computer in a cabinet is not the best thing. There is restricted ventilation.
i was going to get 200mm fans for ventilation, but i thikn it'll just end up on a shelf
we're being admonished
anyway, the point is the 90* isn't sustained under normal conditions, so it shoudl be ok for now
the main point is that the fan speed increases whether in Ubuntu or Windows with the increase of CPU usage. It is just a preventive measure to stop burnout.
i was able to force the fan to high with umm... some package in the repos, but it only did it for a second, so i set up a script on startup to run the command every .5 seconds :)
one of them monitoring programs, not gkrellm though
there are Windows software to test the extreme usage of the CPU, I don't know if there is one for Ubuntu. Perhaps someone can enlighten us on that.
what the software does is exhausts every conceivable mathematical computation that a CPU can make and tests the heat of the component and the durability of the CPU.
i just stream 720p video to stress it
I don't see any problem with your system. On a very hot day, your CPU will be cooking.
